comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/] Sorry to have to disagree again about "first naval fleet" (1891), but this photo is much more recent - the liner looks too modern for 1891.  The lighthouse at Bradleys Head was built in 1905 and Robertsons (Cremorne) Point in 1910.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Looks like a regatta flagship. 1920s or 1930s due to the launches not being steam-powered,  if you know what I mean.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Done! It was a bit optimistic hoping for more first fleet images...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 39967544@N00
comment._content:
The liner is either the Demosthenes or its outwardly identical sister Themistocles, both completed for the Aberdeen Line in 1911, with a yellow funnel. In 1928 both were transferred to the White Star Line Australia service, with the colour scheme of the illustrated ship. The Demosthenes was laid up mid 1931 and soon scrapped. Themistocles survived war service and was not dismantled until 1947.
It does indeed seem that the large ship in the photo is the Regatta flagship, and being a pre-WW2 photo it must be dated between 1928 and 1939. So it's more likely that the liner is the Themistocles.
nb - the tags to naval ships seem incorrect.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39967544@N00] Thanks FredV45 - 'Themistocles' it is! The occasion was "The Ninety-sixth Anniversary Day Regatta" on Thursday 26 January 1933. See SMH 27/1/1933 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16948498 and trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16948458 (reference here to a "sea serpent" - didn't we see something like that in one of these photos a while back?). Frederick Garner Wilkinson was also floating around the same day - emuseum.anmm.gov.au/code/emuseum.asp?id=141218
